title: 108_hr2404
content: The Act is titled the "Theodore Roosevelt Commemorative Coin Act" and includes findings. Theodore Roosevelt, born on October 27, 1858, in New York City, was a prominent figure in American history. He served in various roles such as a representative in the New York State Assembly, Commissioner of the New York City Police Department, Assistant Secretary of the Navy, and Governor of New York. He also organized the Rough Riders during the Spanish-American War. Theodore Roosevelt, born in New York City in 1858, served as the 25th Vice-President and later became the 26th President of the United States. He played a significant role in foreign affairs, established the US as a world power, and implemented reforms on labor, monopolies, and conservation. In 2001, he was posthumously awarded the Congressional Medal of Honor for his actions during the Spanish-American War. Theodore Roosevelt was the first American to receive the Nobel Peace Prize in 1906 for his role in ending the Russo-Japanese War. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue $1 silver coins with rough rider and adventurer designs, each weighing 26.73 grams, having a diameter of 1.500 inches, and containing 90% silver and 10% copper. These coins will be legal tender. The coins minted under this Act, containing 90% silver and 10% copper, will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. Congress recommends striking the coins at the United States Mint at West Point, New York. The design of coins minted under this Act will contain 90% silver and 10% copper, and will be considered legal tender and numismatic items. Congress suggests striking the coins at the United States Mint in West Point, New York. The coins minted under this Act will be emblematic of President Theodore Roosevelt's life and legacy, using designs by James Earle Fraser or Augustus Saint-Gaudens. The $1 coins will feature Theodore Roosevelt as a Rough Rider on the obverse. The reverse of the coins minted under section 3(a)(1) will bear the eagle design from the $20 gold "double eagle" coin designed by Augustus Saint-Gaudens. The $1 coins minted under section 3(a)(2) will feature Theodore Roosevelt on horseback, based on James Earle Fraser's equestrian statue of Roosevelt at the American Museum of Natural History in New York City. The reverse of the coins minted under section 3(a)(2) will bear a design based on James Earle Fraser's reverse designs for the Roosevelt Memorial Association Medal of Honor and Founders Medal, depicting a flaming sword of righteousness and the quotation "If I". The coins minted under this Act will bear a design based on James Earle Fraser's reverse designs, depicting a flaming sword of righteousness and the quotation "If I Must Choose Between Righteousness and Peace, I Choose Righteousness." The coins will also feature inscriptions of various words including "Liberty", "In God We Trust", and "United States of America". The design for the coins will be selected by the Secretary after consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts. The citizens advisory committee established under section 5135 of title 31, United States Code reviewed the design for the coins minted under this Act. Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities starting January 1, 2006, with sales possible before that date. Minting authority will terminate on December 31, 2006. The Secretary will sell coins at face value plus the cost of designing and issuing. Bulk sales will be at a discount, and prepaid orders will receive a reasonable discount. Coins can be sold individually or as sets. Surcharges will apply. SEC. 7. SURCHARGES. Sales of coins will include a $10 surcharge per coin. The surcharges will be paid to the Theodore Roosevelt Association for educational programs at Sagamore Hill National Historic Site. The Association will be audited as per the requirements of the law.
